pros: Co workers, health insurance and unlimited PTO
cons: job canoe stressful at times.

review_title: Good place to get experience, not sustainable long term
job_title: Licensed Mental Health Therapist in Puyallup, WA
pros: I like my Healthcare coverage. I'm happy with my PTO. I like how my PM is not micro-manage-y. I like how I can go to the office outside of business hours to catch up on notes when needed. I received a $7 raise when I became fully licensed ($1000 more each month!).
cons: We're expected to have 55 or more clients on our caseload. Many clients are complex and at high risk for suicide yet we do not have the availability to offer most of them weekly sessions. Seeing clients once every 3-4 weeks does not seem like good clinical care. We do not have a dedicated case manager which is frustrating when I'm trying to get help with resources for clients. The clinical supervisors they have hired are very inexperienced (except for 1 I can remember) and do not offer much clinical advice. Most have not even been able to sign off on hours for supervision because they haven't been licensed long enough. Sea Mar does not provide enough training for new staff on the EHR. Other therapists have to train new staff. The office building is old and needs a lot of repairs. It looks dirty on the outside and inside. Lots of clutter and gross smells in the building. Kitchens are dirty.

pros: Good learning experience in the medical field.
cons: Lots of turnover. Management can inprove

review_title: Absolute Hot Mess of a Company
job_title: Medical Records Specialist in Bellingham, WA
pros: Absolutely none whatsoever. This work is not fulfilling.
cons: Horribly managed, huge turnaround, terrible pay, disorganized mess. This company will kick you to the curb in a heartbeat and outsource your job overseas.

review_title: Avoid at all costs.. because it will cost you.
job_title: Mental Health Worker in Bellingham, WA
pros: None that I can think of.
cons: SeaMar has some amazing medical staff, but management and HR are horrific and I would caution anyone from working here. I was given 4 incorrect job titles in 3 years of employment. During the pandemic, following a year of direct patient contact, SeaMar provided me my 1st COVID vaccine, but cancelled the 2nd with only hours notice, leaving me to find it on my own. The biggest issue was pay: multiple payroll errors that totalled $14,000 over 3 years of work. When I brought this data (my paystubs compared to the rate of pay I was promised when hired) to management, they denied any error, claimed I had been overpaid, and was lucky they weren't asking me to reimburse them. I filed a grievance with the union, which was useless. Don't think you will get any advocacy from them -- my pay decreased AGAIN when I joined the union. After a year debating my case, they closed it, stating that because I was never given an offer letter, they had 'no paper trail' They noted SeaMar has a reputation for doing this. Avoid working for this organization if at all possible. There are enough smaller healthcare organizations that will treat you with much more respect and professionalism, and are far more likely pay you what you're promised upon hire.

pros: The back office staff have good team work and are pleasant to work with. Great for starting out at for the experience working with lower income population and the fact that we see and hear it all here at sea mar your day will never be boring.
cons: Management can play favorites, heavy work load pay does not compensate, very fast paced, overall very stressful place to work.

pros: floor staff who work there are cool
cons: this place has horrible management, the bilittle you so much

pros: Great team, good benefit package
cons: Frequent turnover and repetitive paperwork

pros: Very well organized group. Staff are well trained!
cons: not that I can remember

pros: Excellent benefits for full-time employees. Most nights and weekends off. The non-managerial staff has union protections and salary bargaining.
cons: All staff - top to bottom - are overextended. To increase profit Sea Mar seems to operate with minimal staffing. This increases the workloads and lengths of the work day for most staff in order to accomplish task completion on time. High turnover of front-line staff.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant (CMA) in Aberdeen, WA
pros: UNION. Good benefits. They have their own pharmacy you can fill your rxs for no cost. They help a lot of people who need the help and have tons of resources to get patients the help the need. There are wonderful providers who work here, who truly care about their patients.
cons: High turnover of employees. The amount of referrals generated in a single day. You don't feel like you can ask for help. A constant feeling of drowning due to constantly being understaffed. Cannot trust anything out of the nurse managers mouth. So when you cannot trust your manager what do you do?

pros: Good benefits Drs are very professional

job_title: Integrated Mental Health Therapist in Tacoma, WA
pros: This is a great way to grow as a new clinician. The supervision I have had has been pretty excellent and supportive of my growth. My job and role are easy to understand because of this and the education dept at Sea Mar creates training and guides that make the technology used fairly easy to learn. I find the mission and vision of the organization to be a major reason why I continue to invest my time and energy into this role.
cons: The medical side of the organization has very little understanding of mental health care and function with a primary goal of productivity. This productivity is directly related to billable services and providers are pressured to maintain efficiency instead of prioritizing patient recovery. The annual review of providers in all departments highlights productivity rates that align more with capitalism than with the organization's mission and vision statement. Luckily, my role is protected from these standards because of the obvious job description that does not include many billable services.

job_title: Health Information Management Clerk in Bellingham, WA

Some dedicated health "professionals", trapped in a horrible place, but still care.

Comedy golden, as you will love how bad it's run
cons:
They use federal money and outsourced records to India, year turn around time now, lol.

As union Steward, discovered money is primary goal of management, will lie at all costs to protect there bonuses.

You will make below scale

COVID numbers are not accurate, not even close.

Dirty place with no security, you will have unlocked doors, here people scream in anger, car will probably get hurt.

They only pretend to care about the Mexican population, management goal is revenue not quality of care

The management opportunities for nurses are there, but they expect an insane amount of time. We are talking 50+ hours each and every week, because you're salary. Nurses, explore your options first!!!

pros: Clinical supervisors are professional and get back to you in a short amount of time. Good amount of PTO, and other benefits.
cons: Community mental health is challenging and complex work, especially in a medical/care team format. There are nuances of ethics to be considered in many steps of the position, but it is rewarding. A lot of crisis stabilization, case management, and referrals made. Good for clients, but can take up a lot of your time. I don’t necessarily consider this to be a con, but if you’re looking for private practice work, in a clinical setting... This isn’t it.

cons: If you've ever worked in an MCO (managed care organization) or Federally funded program you know what the cons are. Sea Mar makes the best of it. But you will be under the thumb of massive insurance and care standards that will bog down the best of us.

review_title: Like some parts, disappointed with others.
pros: Love the dedication the company has to serving diverse communities and taking a strong stand with social justice and community service. Seems to be very easy to get hired because of a high turnover rate so if you're desperate for a job fast, chances seem pretty good.
cons: There are a lot of employees cutting corners. Also employees who were maybe hired because they were the ones willing to work for less. Pay is super low compared to other salaries I've seen out there and it doesn't seem like they were attracting the cream of the crop with the bare bones compensation. The most responsible and dedicated people I talked to during my stay confided that they were just there to get the experience they felt they needed to get into other places. It's too bad because many great workers there struggle to make a difference among the masses who don't seem to care.

review_title: Great Mission, Weak Infrastructure, Lack of Support
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South Seattle, WA
pros: Sea Mar has a great mission and health care providers who do care.
cons: Sad situation behind the scenes. CEO is growing the business fast but not providing the required infrastructure and supports, such as IT and Training and Accounting and... serious trouble in many of the departments and people are treading water. Inexperienced or unskilled workers are hired in at low wages and expected to fend for themselves, while longer term experienced employees feel taken advantage of, unappreciated, of forced to keep quiet. Numerous people have tried saying something but quit when not listened to - others have quit because they're afraid to say anything about the level of mismanagement. There are big bucks in CEO hands while office employees are crammed several people in the space for one, old leaky buildings, system computers have gone down several times due to outdated equipment so employees have to work on paper then have a huge backlog...  long list of items needing attention.

review_title: I enjoyed my actual job, but:
job_title: Group Life Counselor in Bellingham, WA
pros: I worked at the SeaMar Visions Treatment facility. I enjoyed working with the adolescents
cons: Clinical supervisor is very negative. She needs training in motivating employees and positive management skills. When you're meeting with employees, the employee should feel good about the meeting, rather than being sent back to the floor downtrodden and discouraged. Supervisor is very hands off. I witnessed her abruptly directing a staff about where she should be in front of the patients. Very clear favoritism to certain employees. A large number of employees in the position of Group Life Counselor are very young. At times they were very cliquish, and it was difficult to connect with them. Sometimes one wondered if it was a fashion show, rather than a workplace. If you are young and pretty, the clinical supervisor treated you better. Young employees broke rules constantly with no reprimands. During my time there there were two girls on "suicide watch" These girls clearly needed help from a psychotherapist,  and clinical supervisor seemed to not have a clear understanding of their needs.

pros: The mission statement is great. Working for the community was what I wanted to do in the beginning. Patients can be a handful sometimes,  but honestly,  they wouldn't be going to the clinic of they felt great. Great diversity among patients and friendly coworkers. Great benefits and is a union job.
cons: You are hired for one specific position but quickly get thrown into various positions. Management can be dismissing and uncooperative. High turnover rate due to over scheduling and burnout. Poor time management on providers causing extreme wait times. Very little advancement opportunities. Compensation does not reflect experience. Clinic managers need to vouch more for their employees and be in the clinic more than out of it. Also,  upper management needs to complete one task before beginning new ones. Also,  call center and CSR get paid almost as much as medical assistants,  do less and do not have similar education. Pay the assistants according to education and experience.

pros: Inspiring mission statement, noble goals, good programs for those marginalized by society, can attract high caliber providers and I have seen many of them, including myself, give it their all in terms of patient care and kindness
cons: High provider burnout, management using punitive practices that spread fear and intimidation, which should be embarrassing to anyone working in the heath fields but especially those mental health, patients suffer multiple provider losses, heard the term at a recent management meeting that Sea Mar is "bleeding providers", special preference is given to others regardless of educational level and experience with unilateral decisions made at high levels, providers are required to work and split their attention between multiple job sites.

pros: Good intentions & majority of Staff are there to do good work.
cons:
All this time I thought they were a great company.

They are now pushing out a new policy for Mandatory Influenza Vaccinations.

They are pushing the agenda with SCARE tactics: Also known as Fearmongering.
*Threats: Putting your job on the line.
*Sympathy: Misleading you into believing it is about patient & staff safety care.
*Guilt: If you do not comply then you are putting others at risk.

What they are not telling you that it is about Data for CDC/ACIP in exchange for Money.
That is right! Your vaccination data will be given to the GOV involuntarily. You will be their test subject.

This is all under Value Based Purchasing and Reductions to Medicare and Medicaid Reimbursements. Also known as Hospital VBP Program covered in the Affordable Care Act.
 
412.160 through 412.167 published in the Federal Register /Vol. 77, No. 170 / Friday, August 31, 2012 /Rules and Regulations 53675 (1)

In order for them to comply with part of the program they need 90% of their staff vaccinated with the influenza. Each employee is worth 2.0% as 2017 and will continue to increase over the year.

Is your personal health only worth 2.0%?

SeaMar is not a non profit organization, they will profit off of you.

job_title: Family Medicine Physician in Vancouver, WA
pros: Generous PTO and holiday time. Salary adequate. Benefits adequate.  Honorable mission of providing medical access to the under/uninsured.  Large company.
cons: Management at all levels disinterested in employee input.  Very totalitarian environment. Inexperienced and unqualified personnel in management positions making very basic mistakes that cause great rancor among the employees. Low morale as a result.

job_title: Physical Therapist in White Center, WA
pros: The physical therapy department at SeaMar is interdisciplinary and provides efficient care.  The  physical therapist works directly with sports medicine physicians and primary care physicicans with a seamless referral process.  The work is very rewarding and the clinic staff is compassionate and driven towards providing comprehensive, meaningful, and community-based care.
cons: The physical therapy department is relatively new and will continue to need ongoing administrative attention, however, this is an opportunity for a physical therapist to be included in the development and direction of the program.   It is important for details of the daily job requirements to be clearly represented and clearly agreed upon with all parties involved.  It is also important to determine the most efficient documentation system for physical therapy in order to optimize time spent in patient care.

review_title: In 10 years in the field of Behavioral Health, this is the worst experinece I have ever had in my working life.
pros: I'm impressed with the Mission Statement and overall goal of this organization to provide medical and mental health services to immigrant and other under-served populations trying to survive and thrive in this country.
cons: As CDP with more than 10 years in the field I can say that my experience as an employee at SeaMar was the worst in my working life.  To put it mildly, the environment was abusive, toxic, and unethical in it's practices. My time as an employee at Sea Mar ruined my love of the field. I warn anyone considering employment here to stay away.

job_title: Certified Medical Receptionist in Bellingham, WA
pros: Management for the front desk  overall  is great. has a open door policy. I’m  able to talk with my boss anytime, and  was given an opportunity to work in the clinic even for being over 45 years old. Went to school and became a certified medical receptionist but did not get this job until four years after school. Most staff work together with each other and help each other out.
cons: Some staff like to gossip as with any job, and management doesn’t always correct situations that arise. .

job_title: Child and Family Therapist in Everett, WA
pros: Pays higher than industry standard and offers good PTO. The VP above me, Claudia, is excellent at understanding organizational needs and individual needs. I trust her. She's just spread too thin.
cons: The management structure is very hierarchal and appears to struggle with communication. Change happens very slowly and sometimes too late to hold on to talent. The company has strict dress code policies resonant with long ago office culture.

job_title: Clinical Support Staff in Seattle, WA
pros: Positive Company Mission, and  a genuinely important resource that meets a need providing services to populations that might otherwise not be treated or have opportunities for multiple helping services.
cons: Sea Mar does not recognize the dysfunctional family model that they teach their individuals about is also the model the facility I worked in used for staff. The Addictive, Co-dependent, Hero, Scapegoat and Nurturer are fully represented. And  if you do not want to be a part of the dysfunction, you will earn the Scapegoat designation. Most people in Chemical Dependency work have a background in abuse, and if the management is dysfunctional, it is easy for the staff to follow. A lot of throwing other employees in front if the train to save themselves, false accusations, and inciting suspicions.

review_title: No infrastructure to support management needs and forced "volunteer" work
pros: Sea Mar has a great mission and some of the most dedicated staff you will ever encounter.  People generally get along well with each other and respect one another.  Very friendly for the most part and everyone there suffers together, forming strong and lasting bonds.
cons: Managers and Directors are forced to do menial tasks and become experts in areas where they are not supposed to be spending their time.  They find themselves responsible for becoming EMR template builders, HR paperwork and policy specialists, Infection Control supervisors, event planners, and JCAHO auditors and writers.  People who are supposed to be managing the work of teams or developing departments must instead focus on putting out fires every day, filling out useless reports, dealing with constant staff turnover (at last check it was 35% first year turnover rate), doing at least 4 different jobs, dealing with incompetent coworkers or supervisors because quite frankly, they can't and don't attract the best talent (or they fail to keep them due to the pure insanity of it all) and being forced to volunteer weekend and weeknight hours to at least 6 different community events throughout the year.  Yes, forced.  If you are a supervisor, it is mandatory to plan, coordinate, staff and participate in these events.  Probably illegal but this organization is run by fear, so no one is empowered enough to address it.  They are an organization of about 1,200 staff and their HR department has only 4 staff, Payroll has 2, IT has 10 and there is one Quality Director responsible for implementing JCAHO throughout the entire organization, with no staff or support.  You tear your hair out every day while working here, because for every one step forward, you take two steps back.  Impossible.

pros: Benefits are great,  The staff who are actually in tune with the patients are good people.
cons: Seattle Corporate is completely out of touch with what is really going on. VP are allowed to act more like a dictator when the implications are disastrous. Constant micromanagement occurs with little room for managers to do their job.  Moral of staff is always low with high turnover rates.  Pay is poor, but Executive people make great money.  If your good with feeling like your overwhelmed, then this is the place for you.

job_title: Community Resource Navigator in Seattle, WA
pros: Great health insurance benefits, easy to navigate and explore departments-especially helpful if you're trying to rise up in the departments.
cons: You may be offered one day of semi-helpful training, two at most. A lot of the work is learn-as-you-go. Great because it challenges you to be curious and seek out answers. Bad because if we don't know what is offered we can't help the patients. Also lots of red tape from management. Also it's a community health center so you'll be safe to assume the pay  is not the best.

review_title: Dream job that ended up being a nighmare
job_title: Dental Assistant III in Port Angeles, WA
pros: Solid hours, challenging, great service to the community, wonderful providers, no waiting period on healthcare coverage(starts on the 1st day of work)
cons: Very long hiring waiting period(months between being offered the position to an actual start date)  . overload of duties and patients without any overtime wiggle room to have it all under care. Must complete off site orientation (usually weeks after actually starting) before even being able to log into the computer to take an x-ray or help provider with charting.

review_title: Terrible, very poorly run organization with terrible treatment of staff and providers.
pros: Great benefits, PTO, CME. Noble cause in serving underinsured and uninsured. No more pros, so I'll just restate benefits, PTO and CME
cons: There is absolutely no communication between admin and staff. Changes are never announced ahead of time and are simply implemented without thought or logic. Things are run in a very authoritarian way, employees are not trusted and there is no respect for the employees. The clinics are an absolute disaster, dirty and disorganized. It's an embarrassment. There's too much more to say....think carefully about working for this agency

job_title: Registered Dietitian in Federal Way, WA
pros: Great team at Federal Way and Kent Medical clinics along with flexible and efficient RD supervisor. Opportunity to work with very diverse patient population. Good PTO, medical benefits, many paid holidays. 4% raise per year in the union.  Potential for broad scope of topics for MNT.
cons: Not every RD gets an office space and there is overlap of nutrition education with the Health Educator role, which confuses patients. Salary position limits overtime compensation. Repetitive topics for MNT. High turnover for all positions.

pros: Serving patients, great managers/supervisors, and rewarding work. If you can work here in it's negative culture, everywhere else will feel like you're treated like gold.
cons: The management structure is designed for micromanagement and distrust of staff. Front line leadership is given little to no support, training, or respect. Executives prefer to focus on negative, leading to staff not being engaged and not meeting organizational goals.

job_title: Vice President Operations in Seattle, WA
pros: This community is truly representative of the community and its needs. It was built as community based organization and has stayed that way for forty years. Sea Mar employs many great individuals that choose to be a part of the organization rather than simply collect a paycheck.
cons: The geographic spread of clinics or locations can make implementation of practices or policies difficult in some situations. However, a lot of work has been done in recent years to improve this.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist I in Kent, WA
pros: Has great talented employees, with the passion to serve their community.  The company provides great benefits (with the exception that they don't match retirement).
cons: The work case load is high, you have to wear many hats with multiple job responsibilities, and high burn out rate. Company is disorganized administratively (at least the area of mental health was, cant speak for the medical or dental side of work) and doesn't pay according to the workload.

review_title: Wonderful, fulfilling work with disadvantaged populations
job_title: Clinical Support Staff in Seattle, WA
pros: Direct care for under-served populations, serves diverse patient demographic, offers wide array of patient services, clinical staff are very caring and compassionate, great mid level management
cons: Select few high up admin staff practice a dictator style management, can be fired for random reasons/ going on maternity leave. CEO earns roughly 1 million every year, while many clinical full time staff are on food stamps and very low income

job_title: Group Life Counselor in Bellingham, WA
pros:
Great experience, the job also attracts the most compassionate employees to help you get through the hard times. Management has the ability to make change if you actually bring certain things to their attention.

The work hours are rigid and a bit odd, but it worked out perfectly for my personal schedule.
cons: Disconnect between floor staff and management, seemed more annoyed by conflict than willing to find a solution as a team. Sometimes the actions add to the negative atmosphere of an already tense work environment.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Seattle, WA
pros:
Benefits are good and good paid time off
Management accommodates staff too take time off
All cultures and backgrounds are recognized here 
Patients are friendly and so happy to receive care here
Former close friends from work and we are like a tight knit community of people here
Staff celebrates employees birthdays and other special occasions as well as holiday events
cons:
Not paid on time and it’s an ongoing problem
We are not paid on time and it’s been 3 weeks since a paycheck 
Management doesn’t understand what goes on in the clinic and shows favoritism 
Lazy, rude and incompetent staff not trained properly by management  team either

pros: Generous benefits, especially for managers and supervisors. Vacation and sick leave combined into PTO. If you choose a Sea Mar PCP, there's no copay for visits or prescriptions.
cons: Very low pay for frontline staff, super bureaucratic structure, lack of communication from management, high turnover/burnout, punitive personnel policies (managers expected to discipline staff who arrive one minute late). Very old school and top-down approaches to employees. Managers required to volunteer for organization-sponsored events in addition to 40-hour work week. No flex time.

pros:
Sea Mar provides bilingual English & Spanish language health services in Washington state. 
This company has an ethic of assuring that people receive necessary health care, regardless of ability to pay.
cons: Because Sea Mar offers health services at or below cost, there is some dependence on grant funding that is not a secure revenue stream.

job_title: Group Life Counselor in Bellingham, WA
pros: As a Group Life Counselor for their Visions sector, I had the ability to work with the clients directly and make a visible difference in their time at Visions.
cons: There is a severe lack of advancement opportunities.

review_title: Dangerous Clinics to Work At or Be Associated With
pros:
Benefits 
Mostly Decent Co-Workers
Getting to work with the under served population
Lots of learning opportunities within clincs
cons: The pay is a joke. A lot of the staff is on government assistance thanks to the fact that the CEO and top level management is making close to 1 million dollars a year. Dangerous care is being given in the clinics to fill HEDIS measures that make up a big chunk of the government funding that Sea Mar gets in a year, with little consideration that is given to the actual reason that the pt went in that day. All lower staff are treated like trash and it only gets worse with time and new implementations that are being rolled out every other month with no formal training. Turn over is 30% which is why they are always hiring. The compensation does not equal the amount of work that is given. Many staff do not know how to properly interpret different languages without using slang, providers are burnt out after the 2 year contract and most end up leaving. A whole urgent care department in Seattle was closed down due to people quitting. The union will take your money, but do not handle things in a timely manner and more often than not, you would have been better off keeping your mouth shut. Management is retaliatory and most clinic managers are unprofessional and some are college dropouts. If they can't finish school, how can they run a clinic? READ THE REST OF THE REVIEWS.  This is not a fluke comment. This is the consensus.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Seattle, WA
pros: Nothing unless you like working without any appreciation from management. If you like 16 hr shifts I guess you will do well. The money is one of the lowest in the business. And believe me for Sea mar it is a business. People are a distant second.
cons: Management does not care. Always short staffed. High turnover. Any good staff leave when they get better offers. Even supervisors are not valued by stuck up managers. They burn you out and discard you when you get frustrated.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Lacey, WA
pros:
Generous benefits
Good community outreach and programs available 
Nice patients 
Diverse cultures 
Enjoyed working with families as had a close knit team of coworkers that were incredibly helpful during my first few weeks here.
cons:
EMPLOYEES NOT PAID ON TIME repeatedly and management  isn’t too concerned fixing the problem
Nothing changes once you have a well thought out conversation with senior management
Favoritism among managers and some staff members
Lazy managers and staff that doesn’t enforce the rules or do there jobs appropriately.
Polices are just thrown together and not well thought out or explained to employees

pros: The work is very rewarding. There are a lot of staff members that are passionate about providing quality care to underserved populations.
cons: The pay is really low for a position that requires a masters level education. High turn over due to the low pay.

review_title: Do yourself a favor and find another company
job_title: Registered Nurse in White Center, WA
pros:
Let’s start with the positive. We get good benefits, generous PTO, maternity leave and paid medical leave. My manager was professional and knowledgeable but most here aren’t.
I loved working with the patients as well. Diversity and culture it great here as well.
cons: We haven’t received any pay for over 2 months. Upper management is horrific and doesn’t care at all about anyone but their own fat wallets. This is probably my worst career experience in my life. Management is definitely shady and rude to lower paid staff. Acts like they are better in some way.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Tacoma, WA
pros: good benefits for medical , dental and vision.
cons: Management has their favorites, i was due to have surgery a procedure that was needed and they would not allow me PTO to have my surgery and yes this was after my 90 days.

review_title: The department I am a part of is wonderful.
pros: Care Management Department. Vacation days. Everyone works as a team and is willing to help out other counties.
cons: High turnover. Upper management not understanding what department really does. Takes a long time to get items needed to improve work capabilities.

pros: Given "in the trenches" experience, cross-functional team utilization, everyday user experience situations, passionate people, develop new ideas
cons: New Ideas aren't always implemented, slow to improve processes, no financial autonomy for site, little info/resources to create something new

job_title: Health Information Clerk in Bellingham, WA
pros: Mindless work for a decent paycheck, Free Health Insurance for self, paid holidays. Union
cons: Erratic scheduling, surprise 10 hour shifts, or 6 day work weeks. Disorganized management, Problems are fixed by throwing money at them because solving them is to inconvenient. Union

pros: Insurance (if you stay within Sea Mar clinics/programs)
cons: Insurance (outside of Sea Mar's clinics/programs), management, pay, drama, lack of communication

pros: I enjoy the work and is quite rewarding if you seek to help population in need.
cons: Program manager spread to thin. Barely present unable to supervised when needed or provide feedback. Co-workers unwilling to be proactive and go above and beyond for the customer.

pros: The organization provides amazing health care services to low income families. It's financially sound. Providers and supporting staff are very committed to serve the community.
cons: There is not available budget for competitive compensation or professional development or training for staff.

job_title: Clinical Support Staff in South Seattle, WA
pros: Benefits are incredible and cost nothing to you as an employee. For Sea Mar medical visits with a Sea Mar PCP cost you nothing too.
cons: No comment regarding this field as I have nothing derogatory to mention about this great employer or the benefits that are provided.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Des Moines, WA
pros: Competitive salary and benefits including health care and ample vacation
cons: There are a lot of levels of management and bureaucracy making the organization too structured and not adaptable to clients or staff needs.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Vancouver, WA
pros: Great teamwork environment,  positivity shown and encouraged
cons: Need full time position and not available

review_title: Large organization ran like a Mom and Pop business
pros: Supervisors get lots of paid time off and copays are very low
cons: Upper Management doesn't listen to front line staff, low wages for front line staff, unorganized, management style is very top-down just do it because I said so.  Many plans are not thought out before implementation which always turns into last ditch efforts.

pros:
The Purchasing Department staff rocks the boat, is very friendly, and hard working.
The Administrative Supervisor is supportive, clearly very caring.
cons:
Location in Seattle - hard to get to.
Some job positions prefer Spanish speakers over English speakers.

pros: Great learning opportunity, mission-driven leaders, support and development of leadership skills benefical
cons: Difficulties exist for managers of clinics lacking support from subordinate supervisory staff

job_title: Executive Assistant in South Seattle, WA
pros: Learn to multi task and meet a lot of people.
cons: Under valued employees. High turnover. No room for growth.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Tacoma, WA
pros: Health insurance, free to visit Sea Mar providers and to use their pharmacy. Generous PTO accrual. A lot of available discounts for being an employee.
cons: Pay for nurses isn't very good.

review_title: Good place to start, not to stay.
pros: Great ability to accrue vacation time, 1/2 a day each pay period.
cons: No ability to negotiate salary. No schedule flexibility. Disorganized work culture, lack of consistencey in cultures/protocols across clinics.

job_title: Community Health Worker in Olympia, WA
pros:
Work in a multilingual, multicultural environment 
Serving low income individuals
cons:
High turnover
Horrible upper management-totally detached from clinics and programs 
Difficult to move up
Extremely disorganized 
Low pay 
Overwork and underpay

review_title: Good place to make a difference
job_title: Clinical Lab Assistant in Marysville, WA
pros: Excellent providers, skilled medical assistants, accessible
cons: pay could be better, but it's a community health center. So it's understandable.

review_title: Terrible Work Environment With Focus on Money Grabbing HEDIS Measures
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Monroe, WA

review_title: Case manager in care management department home health

review_title: Local office is great, overall company only so so

pros: Good program manager and supervisors. Like clients and that company is big on social justice.
cons: Gossipy coworkers, some management appears shady,

pros: Wonderful organizational mission and great majority of employees are well-intentioned and very caring professionals.

cons: Working with youth is a privilege but it can also be emotionally draining.

pros: Job security. There is room to move up and excel in a position
